content: Something I find mildly frustrating is that the main argument against 1559 feels like, "the network is currently attackable, and 1559 makes it more attackable. author: .vbuterin
content: btw another really fun fact is that even if you're skeptical of bursts, EIP 1559 is *definitely* safe enough when we do eth2 üòÜ  The reason is that PoW because of its poisson distribution of block times has a naturally spiky block distribution, and we get a 5-minute-long capacity doubling on average about once a week, but eth2 has blocks cleanly coming once per 12 seconds, so this no longer is a problem

author: .vbuterin
content: And so EIP 1559 just comes in and replaces the bursts that PoW used to already provide

author: timbeiko
content:
> To clarify, the question is, are the attacks people are worried about (i) super-linear wrt gas in a block, (ii) super-linear wrt gas in a transaction or (iii) linear but with high constant factors

My hunch is that the "broken metre"-type attacks are maybe super-linear wrt gas in a block (e.g. if we can create a bad block now that just slows the network down, a 2x bad block may do worse than that, for example crashing the node). I don't see why (ii) would be the case, and no idea on (iii). I'll follow up and try and provide a better answer.
